sent: GeoGebra's creator, Markus Hohenwarter, started the project in 2001 (as part of his master's thesis) at the University of Salzburg, continuing it at Florida Atlantic University (2006-2008), Florida State University (2008-2009), and now at the University of Linz together with the help of open-source developers and translators all over the world.
The original ownCloud developer Frank Karlitschek forked ownCloud and created Nextcloud, which continues to be actively developed by Karlitschek and other members of the original ownCloud team.
GNU Parted was written by Andrew Clausen and Lennert Buytenhek.
Newsbeuter was originally written by Andreas Krennmair in 2007 and released under the MIT License.

Sonic Pi is a live coding environment based on Ruby, originally designed to support both computing and music lessons in schools, developed by Sam Aaron in the University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory in collaboration with Raspberry Pi Foundation.
GNU Parted was written by Andrew Clausen and Lennert Buytenhek.
OpenVPN was written by James Yonan and is published under the GNU General Public License (GPL).
TeX (/tx, tk/, see below), stylized within the system as TeX, is a typesetting system (or a "formatting system") which was designed and mostly written by Donald Knuth and released in 1978.
Realm of Nauga is an adventure game for the TRS-80 Color Computer released on cassette as part of Chromasette's August 1982 issue, then available at RadioShack.

Telengard continued to develop DND at Purdue University as a hobby, rewrote the game for the Commodore PET 2001 after 1978, and ported it to Apple II+, TRS-80, and Atari 800 platforms before Avalon Hill found the game at a convention and licensed it for distribution.
BurgerTime (, BÄgÄtaimu) is a 1982 arcade game created by Data East initially for its DECO Cassette System.
By 1992 there were also MS-DOS, Atari ST and Amstrad CPC versions available.
Wings of Fury was released in 1989 for the X68000 and in 1990 for Amstrad CPC, Commodore 64, Amiga, and MS-DOS.
From 1985 to 1988, the game was released for the Apple II, Atari 7800, ZX Spectrum, Acorn Electron, BBC Micro, Amstrad CPC, and Master System.
Versions 0.10 to 1.20 were used on the BBC Micro, version 1.00 on the Electron, version 2 was used on the B+, and versions 3 to 5 were used in the BBC Master series.
Zynaps is a side-scrolling shoot 'em up video game published by Hewson Consultants for the ZX Spectrum, Amstrad CPC and Commodore 64 in 1987 and for the Atari ST in 1988 and the Amiga.
OS4000 is a proprietary operating system introduced by GEC Computers Limited in 1977 as the successor to GEC DOS, for its range of GEC 4000 series 16-bit, and later 32-bit, minicomputers.

The game was ported to many home computers by Ocean Software in 1989, including versions for the ZX Spectrum, Amstrad CPC, Commodore 64, MSX, Amiga and Atari ST. Taito produced versions for the Family Computer (1989), Game Boy (1990), Master System (1990), TurboGrafx-16 (1990), Game Gear (1991) and Saturn (1996).

Based on the General Motors Executive System for the IBM 701, UMES was revised to work on the mainframe computers in use at the University of Michigan during this time (IBM 704, 709, and 7090) and to work better for the small student jobs that were expected to be the primary work load at the University.
Berkeley Timesharing System was designed as part of Project Genie and marketed by Scientific Data Systems for the SDS 940 computer system.

WAITS was a heavily modified variant of Digital Equipment Corporation's Monitor operating system (later renamed to, and better known as, "TOPS-10") for the PDP-6 and PDP-10 mainframe computers, used at the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) from the mid-1960s up until 1991; the mainframe computer it ran on also went by the name of "SAIL".
One side had the Atari version, and the other had the Commodore 64 version.
Spacewar ! has also been recreated in more modern programming languages for PDP-1 emulators.
AMSDOS is a disk operating system for the 8-bit Amstrad CPC Computer (and various clones).
PaperClip is a word processor for the Commodore 64, 128 (native mode), and Atari 8-bit family published by Batteries Included in 1985.
007 : Licence to Kill was released for Amiga, Amstrad CPC, Atari ST, BBC Micro, Commodore 64, DOS, MSX and ZX Spectrum.
Versions of the game were released for the Family Computer (1987) and MSX (1988) as Magnum Kiki Ippatsu: Empire City: 1931 ( 1931).
The Datestones of Ryn is a role-playing video game released in 1979 for the Apple II, Commodore PET, and TRS-80 by Automated Simulations (later Epyx).
Audiogenic published versions of the original game for the Acorn Electron, BBC Micro, ZX Spectrum, Amstrad CPC, Commodore 64, Atari ST, Amiga, and IBM PC in 1990 and 1991.
To Preserve Quandic is a graphical adventure game written by David Karam for the TRS-80 Color Computer and published by Prickly Pear Software in 1984.
Transarctica (or Arctic Baron) is a 1993 computer game made by the French company Silmarils for the Amiga and ported to the PC, Atari ST, Macintosh and Atari Falcon.
A version for the Commodore PET by Don Dennis was released July 1979.
Yie Ar Kung-Fu II was released for the Commodore 64, MSX, Amstrad CPC, ZX Spectrum, BBC Micro and Acorn Electron home computer systems and featured a different approach to the game.
750cc Grand Prix was later ported for ZX Spectrum in 1991 by WASP (Lyndon Sharp, Chris Graham and Damon Redmond).
Audiogenic published versions of the original game for the Acorn Electron, BBC Micro, ZX Spectrum, Amstrad CPC, Commodore 64, Atari ST, Amiga, and IBM PC in 1990 and 1991.
Chuckie Egg's popularity saw it released over the following years for the Commodore 64, Acorn Electron, MSX, Tatung Einstein, Amstrad CPC and Atari 8-bit family.
Wargame Construction Set was released for the Amiga, Atari 8-bit family, Atari ST, Commodore 64, and MS-DOS.

Laser Squad is a turn-based tactics video game, originally released for the ZX Spectrum and later for the Commodore 64, Amstrad CPC, MSX, Amiga, Sharp MZ-800 and Atari ST and PC computers between 1988 and 1992.
Army Moves is a scrolling shooter game developed by Dinamic Software for the Amiga, Amstrad CPC, Atari ST, Commodore 64, MSX and ZX Spectrum.
AtariWriter is a word processor for the Atari 8-bit family of home computers published by Atari, Inc. as a 16KB cartridge in 1982.
68K/OS was a computer operating system developed by GST Computer Systems for the Sinclair QL microcomputer.
Rescue on Fractalus ! was also ported to other popular platforms of the day, such as the Apple II, ZX Spectrum (by Dalali Software Ltd), Amstrad CPC, Tandy Color Computer 3 and Commodore 64.
and, in 1982, was converted to the Commodore MAX Machine and Commodore 64.
C-Net DS2 (Developers System, Second Generation) was a full featured, single-line, bulletin board system (BBS) software system released in 1986 for the Commodore 64 microcomputer.

B4X is a suite of rapid application development IDEs and proprietary programming language that allows the creation of applications on the following platforms: Google Android, Apple iOS, Java, Raspberry Pi and Arduino.
Deathchase is a 1983 vehicular combat game written for the ZX Spectrum by Mervyn Estcourt and published by Micromega in the UK.
The Activision Decathlon was ported to the Atari 8-bit family, Atari 5200, Commodore 64, ColecoVision, and MSX.
RT-11 was first implemented in 1970 and was widely used for real-time systems, process control, and data acquisition across the full line of PDP-11 computers.
750cc Grand Prix is a video game originally developed by Ken Murfitt of Scope Soft and published by Codemasters in 1989 for the Amstrad CPC.
The game was published for Acorn Electron, Amstrad CPC, BBC Micro Model B, Commodore 64, Commodore VIC-20, Dragon 32, MSX, Oric Atmos, and ZX Spectrum at Â£8.95 for each part.
Atic Atac is an arcade-adventure video game developed and published by Ultimate Play the Game, released for the ZX Spectrum and the BBC Micro in 1983.
NLTSS ran initially on a CDC 7600 computer, but only ran production from about 1985 until 1994 on Cray computers including the Cray-1, Cray X-MP, and Cray Y-MP models.
Originally developed for BlackBerry in 2006, Ka-Glom ! has since been ported to Java, Windows Mobile, and Apple iOS (iPhone, iPod Touch) devices.

Battle Chess was originally developed and released by Interplay Entertainment for the Amiga in 1988 and subsequently on many other systems, including 3DO Interactive Multiplayer, Acorn Archimedes, Amiga CD32, Amiga CDTV, Apple IIGS, Apple IIe, Atari ST, Commodore 64, MS-DOS, FM Towns, NES, Mac OS, NEC PC-9801, X68000 and Microsoft Windows.
HDOS is an early microcomputer operating system, originally written for the Heathkit H8 computer system and later also available for the Heathkit H89 and Zenith Z-89 computers.
Originating on the TRS-80 and Commodore PET, Temple of Apshai was followed by several updated versions for other computers between 1980 and 1986.
OpenVMS was first released by Digital Equipment Corporation in 1977 as VAX/VMS for its series of VAX minicomputers.
It was succeeded by iPhone OS 3 on June 17, 2009. iPhone OS 2.0 became available on July 11, 2008 with the release of the iPhone 3G.
3D Tanx is a shoot 'em up video game written by Don Priestley and published by DK'Tronics in 1982 for the ZX Spectrum, Commodore 64, and BBC Micro.
LUnix, short for "Little Unix", is a Unix-like multi-tasking operating system designed to run natively on the Commodore 64 and Commodore 128 home computer systems.
The Cray Time Sharing System, also known in the Cray user community as CTSS, was developed as an operating system for the Cray-1 or Cray X-MP line of supercomputers.
Activision later ported the title to the Atari 5200, ColecoVision, and Intellivision consoles, as well as to the Commodore 64, IBM PCjr, MSX, ZX Spectrum, and Atari 8-bit family.
Turner for the BBC Micro home computer and published by Squirrel Software on cassette in 1983 Bun Fun was later ported to the Acorn Electron.
Activision later ported the title to the Atari 5200, ColecoVision, and Intellivision consoles, as well as to the Commodore 64, IBM PCjr, MSX, ZX Spectrum, and Atari 8-bit family.
The iOS 4 update introduced performance and battery problems on iPhone 3G devices, with Apple investigating the matter and promising then-upcoming updates.
Bone Cruncher is a puzzle video game for the Acorn Electron, BBC Micro, and Commodore 64 first published by Superior Software in 1987.

The first version was released in 1982 and spawned two major revisions in addition to several add-ons and, later, tailored versions for the +2 and +3 Spectrum models, the SAM Coupé, the MSX, the Timex TS2068 and the Amstrad CPC range.
Commando Libya is a shoot 'em up for the Commodore 64, written by Robert Pfitzner, and self-published in 1986.

James Pond: Underwater Agent is a platform video game that was developed by British video game developer Millennium Interactive and published by Millennium Interactive and Electronic Arts for the Amiga, Atari ST, Acorn Archimedes, and Sega Genesis.
Wargame Construction Set was released for the Amiga, Atari 8-bit family, Atari ST, Commodore 64, and MS-DOS.
Dedal is a maze video game developed by C. Roman and G. Pollet, released on Oric in 1984.
Halls of the Things is a video game developed by Design Design for the ZX Spectrum and released by Crystal Computing in 1983.
Yie Ar Kung-Fu II was released for the Commodore 64, MSX, Amstrad CPC, ZX Spectrum, BBC Micro and Acorn Electron home computer systems and featured a different approach to the game.
The GM-NAA I/O input/output system of General Motors and North American Aviation was the first operating system for the IBM 704 computer.
Initially released for the Commodore 64 and Apple II, Maniac Mansion was Lucasfilm Games' first self-published product.

sub_label: Return of the Jedi: Death Star Battle
sent: In 1984 Return of the Jedi : Death Star Battle was published for the Sinclair ZX Spectrum.
Canyon Climber is a video game designed by Steve Bjork and James Garon for the TRS-80 Color Computer and published by Tandy Corporation in 1982.
Yie Ar Kung-Fu II was released for the Commodore 64, MSX, Amstrad CPC, ZX Spectrum, BBC Micro and Acorn Electron home computer systems and featured a different approach to the game.
Yie Ar Kung-Fu II was released for the Commodore 64, MSX, Amstrad CPC, ZX Spectrum, BBC Micro and Acorn Electron home computer systems and featured a different approach to the game.
NLTSS ran initially on a CDC 7600 computer, but only ran production from about 1985 until 1994 on Cray computers including the Cray-1, Cray X-MP, and Cray Y-MP models.
Fortress of the Mutant Waffles is a game written for the Radio Shack TRS-80 Color Computer by Andrew Pakerski and published in 1983 by T+D Software.
PaperClip is a word processor for the Commodore 64, 128 (native mode), and Atari 8-bit family published by Batteries Included in 1985.
Initially released in November 2017 with the iPhone X, Face ID has since been updated and introduced to most new iPhone models, and all iPad Pro models.

The game was ported to many home computers by Ocean Software in 1989, including versions for the ZX Spectrum, Amstrad CPC, Commodore 64, MSX, Amiga and Atari ST. Taito produced versions for the Family Computer (1989), Game Boy (1990), Master System (1990), TurboGrafx-16 (1990), Game Gear (1991) and Saturn (1996).

Starglider was originally developed for the 16-bit Amiga and Atari ST. Rainbird commissioned Realtime Games to produce 8-bit versions for the Amstrad CPC, Amstrad PCW, and ZX Spectrum (128K, with a cut-down 48K version without sampled speech or special missions), and also for the IBM-compatible PC running in CGA.

sub_label: Valhalla and the Fortress of Eve
sent: Valhalla and the Fortress of Eve was later ported to PC Windows in 2004 and to the BlackBerry mobile in 2013.
Some controversy existed at LASL with the first attempt to develop an operating system for the Cray-1 named DEIMOS, a message-passing, Unix-like operating system, by Forrest Basket.
California Games is a 1987 Epyx sports video game originally released for the Apple II and Commodore 64 and ported to other home computers and video game consoles.
The phone uses the UIQ 3.0 software platform, which is based upon Symbian OS 9.1.
Nokia Lumia 1020 runs Windows Phone 8, but is also Windows Phone 8.1 ready.
Nokia Lumia 800 originally runs on Windows Phone 7.5 "Mango"-it was Nokia's first device to run the Windows Phone operating system and marked the company's shift from Symbian for their smartphones.
The HTC Touch2 (also known as the HTC T3333 and HTC Mega), is a mobile telephone running the Windows Mobile operating system.
This Treo has a form factor similar to that of the GSM Treo 680, and is equipped with the full Palm OS.
The HD2 natively runs the Windows Mobile 6.5 operating system, and was released in Europe in November 2009, in Hong Kong in December 2009, and in other regions including North America in March 2010.
Sony Ericsson M600 (sold as M600i model in some markets and originally labelled M608c in other markets) is a 3G smartphone based upon the UIQ 3 platform (which is built upon Symbian OS 9.1).
Running the Apple SOS operating system, Apple III was intended as the successor to the Apple II series, but was largely considered a failure in the market.
The PC-5000 was largely IBM PC-compatible, with the same 4.77-MHz Intel 8088 processor as the IBM PC, and ran MS-DOS 2.0 (in ROM).
HTC Artemis or P3300 is a Windows Mobile 5.0 Pocket PC Phone Edition based pocket pc/phone manufactured by High Tech Computer.
The Lumia 950 was the successor to the 2014 Nokia Lumia 930 and is among the first phones to natively run Windows 10 Mobile.
The smartphone was the first to use Palm's Linux based mobile operating system, webOS.

The Windows Mobile 6.1 Professional software suite includes access to the Outlook Mobile email client, as well as mobile versions of Internet Explorer, MSN Messenger, Windows Live and Windows Media Player 10.
The Centro is one of the last-ever devices to run the Palm OS operating system.

The Windows Mobile 6.1 Professional software suite includes access to the Outlook Mobile email client, as well as mobile versions of Internet Explorer, MSN Messenger, Windows Live and Windows Media Player 10.
Like most of HMD's Nokia smartphones, the 9 PureView is part of the Android One program.
The laptop was announced at the #MicrosoftEDU event by Microsoft on May 2, 2017, alongside Windows 10 S and an updated version of Surface Arc Mouse that includes a large capacitive surface.
The Palm Treo 650 is a Palm OS-based smartphone, the successor to Palm's Treo 600.

Redmi 1 comes with a 4.7-inch 720x1080 IPS screen, a MediaTek MT6589T Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A7 processor and originally runs Android 4.2.2 Jellybean with the MIUI v5 user interface, upgradeable to Android 4.4.2 Kitkat with the MIUI 9 user interface.
The HTC Touch HD, also known as the HTC T828X or its codename the HTC Blackstone, is a Windows Mobile 6.1 Pocket PC designed and manufactured by HTC launched in 2008.
Nokia C5-00 runs on Symbian OS with S60 3rd Edition Feature Pack 2.
The XDAndroid project makes HTC Touch Diamond2 possible to run Android on HTC Windows Mobile phones, including the Touch Diamond2.
